--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "kms_avexus <kms_avexus@y...>"
<kms_avexus@y...> wrote:
> **
> ** Replies from J. B. Rainsberger are unwelcome

Well.. this is probably much like what J.B. would say

> I have an EJB that I would like to unit test from my IDE. In other 
> words, I don't want to deploy the bean and it's home/remote/local 
> interfaces. Not yet anyway. I wanted to first test the underlying 
> code. Once that is working, then I'll test the remote invocation of 
> this code.

Consider the EJB as a plumbing layer that you need in order to get
your code to run in the context of the app server.  That is, write as
much code as you can outside the bean, and have the bean be a
facade/delegate  for the purposes of the app server... just like a
Swing GUI should be a plumbing layer/facade/delegate for the purposes
of a human user.

Dave

JB.. how'd I do? :-)
